qas.question: What were the names of some of the early cultures located in Myanmar?

answers.text: Tibeto-Burman-speaking Pyu city-states in Upper Burma and the Mon kingdoms in Lower Burma

qas.question: When did the dominant religion of Myanmar become something outside of the mainstream ?

answers.text: in the 1050s, the Burmese language, culture and Theravada Buddhism slowly became dominant in the country.

qas.question: What caused the downfall of the downfall of the the original kingdom in Myanmar?

answers.text: The Pagan Kingdom fell due to the Mongol invasions and several warring states emerged

qas.question: Whose rule  was Myanmar under when it was one of the most massive kingdoms in Southeast Asia ?
When did was Myanmar ruled by the Taungoo Dynasty ?

context: Early civilisations in Myanmar included the <a0_0>Tibeto-Burman-speaking Pyu city-states in Upper Burma and the Mon kingdoms in Lower Burma<a0_0/>. In the 9th century, the Bamar people entered the upper Irrawaddy valley and, following the establishment of the Pagan Kingdom <a1_0>in the 1050s, the Burmese language, culture and Theravada Buddhism slowly became dominant in the country.<a1_0/> <a2_0>The Pagan Kingdom fell due to the Mongol invasions and several warring states emerged<a2_0/>. <a4_0>In the 16th century<a4_0/>, reunified by the <a3_0>Taungoo Dynasty<a3_0/>, the country was for a brief period the largest empire in the history of Southeast Asia. The early 19th century Konbaung Dynasty ruled over an area that included modern Myanmar and briefly controlled Manipur and Assam as well. The British conquered Myanmar after three Anglo-Burmese Wars in the 19th century and the country became a British colony. Myanmar became an independent nation in 1948, initially as a democratic nation and then, following a coup d'état in 1962, a military dictatorship.
